message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that activates the µ receptor, which causes decreased bowel motility and increased water absorption, leading to relief of diarrhea and abdominal pain. The side effect of constipation is also a common effect of opioids. The other options listed do not play a role in diphenoxylate’s mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that acts on the µ-opioid receptor in the gastrointestinal tract, which reduces motility and secretion, thereby alleviating diarrhea and pain. The side effect of severe constipation is also expected with the activation of this receptor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that activates the µ receptor, leading to decreased intestinal motility and increased fluid absorption, resulting in constipation. The patient experiences relief from her diarrhea and pain due to the same mechanism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist that primarily acts on the µ receptor in the gastrointestinal tract to decrease motility and fluid secretion, which can help relieve diarrhea and cramping. However, it can also cause constipation as a side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that activates µ receptors in the gut, reducing contractions and increasing water absorption, thus leading to constipation. It is used to treat diarrhea but can also cause constipation as a side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that acts on µ receptors to decrease gastrointestinal motility and relieve diarrhea. The atropine component is added to discourage abuse of the medication. The patient’s experience of severe constipation after using diphenoxylate is a known side effect of µ receptor activation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist that activates the µ receptor in the gastrointestinal tract, slowing down peristalsis and decreasing secretions. This helps with diarrhea and cramping but can also cause constipation as a side effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is an opioid that acts on the µ receptor in the intestine to decrease motility and fluid secretion, resulting in constipation. However, it can also cause adverse effects, such as abdominal cramping and bloating.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diphenoxylate is a synthetic opioid that activates the µ receptor in the gut, leading to decreased intestinal motility and increased water absorption, thus reducing diarrhea and abdominal pain. The atropine is added to prevent excessive absorption of the opioid in the gut, which can result in constipation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug diphenoxylate is a µ-opioid receptor agonist which helps to reduce diarrhea and pain. However, it can also cause severe constipation, as mentioned by the patient. None of the other options are related to the mechanism of action of diphenoxylate.
